column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref

#Text=[0151] Although the techniques of the present invention can be used to facilitate both open and minimally invasive abdominal or thoracic aortic aneurysm procedures (or any other aneurysm procedure in the aorta or other areas of the body as well), the following illustration describes only an endovascular minimally invasive repair procedure which is less traumatic to the patient than an open-chest procedure.

#Text=One of ordinary skill in the art, however, will appreciate that the techniques disclosed can be readily applied to open chest procedures as well in which access to the thoracic cavity is achieved through a midline partial or median stemotomy, a mini-thoracotomy incision, or a retroperitoneal incision, for example.

#Text=[0152] In one embodiment of the present invention, it is preferred that the plurality of nanostructures have such composition, density, functionality, etc. so as to impart adhesive properties to the nanostructured surface.
#Text=Such a nanostructured surface is sometimes known in the art as "Nanofur".

#Text=[0153] In one embodiment of the present invention the nanowires of the nanostructured surface are fabricated using a bottom-up catalyst assisted vapor-liquid-solid (VLS) synthetic approach based on the work of Dr.
#Text=Charles Lieber, Harvard University and Dr.

#Text=Peidong Yang, University of California at Berkeley: Cui Y. et al, "Nanowires as Building Blocks for Nanoscale Science and Technology"; Nanowires and Nanobelts: Materials, Properties and Devices, Z.
#Text=L.

#Text=Wang, ed. pp. 3-68 Kluwer Academic/Plenum Publishers (2003) and Qian F. et al., "Core/Multishell Nanowire Heterostructures as Multicolor, High-Efficiency Light-Emitting Diodes," Nano Letters., (5), pp. 2287-2291 (2005), the contents of which are incorporated herein by reference.
#Text=In this method, a metal such as gold particle catalysts with known diameters are deposited from solution on a substrate.
#Text=The substrate is heated to 300.degree.
#Text=C. to 500.degree.
#Text=C.
#Text=(if Au is being used) in the presence of metal hydride or metal halide gas precursor.

#Text=The length of the wires is determined by the growth time and conditions, the diameter is determined by the diameter of the gold catalyst particles used, and the density of wires across the surface is determined by the density of catalyst particles deposited on the surface prior to growth.
#Text=Orientation, branching and the composition of the wires may be controlled by varying synthesis conditions and materials.

#Text=The invention contemplates nanostructured surfaces having one, two, three and/or all sides of a substrate having positioned thereon any desired number and optionally compositionally varied nanostructures (nanowires or nanotubes).

#Text=[0154] Fabrication of nanostructured surfaces in accordance with this invention is possible using a variety of different materials and resulting in a variety of different surface compositions (e.g. nanowire composition), including non-limiting examples such as inorganic materials including inorganic semiconductors such as Si, SiO, SiO2, GaAs, InAs, and medical grade materials such as ZnO and TiO2.
#Text=Nanostructured surfaces in accordance with this invention have been synthesized and some non-limiting examples of which are set forth in Table I below.

#Text=[0155] In one embodiment of manufacture of nanostructured surfaces useful with this invention, the metal (gold, for example) catalysts that define the location and diameter of the nanowires within the nanostructured surface are coated in solution and these films can be fabricated on a variety of substrate materials depending on the end use.
#Text=One skilled in the art will appreciate that the choice of substrate is in part dictated by reaction conditions and nanowire compatibility.

#Text=For certain substrate materials such as Nitinol, titanium or stainless steel, which are common materials used in the medical device industry, in order to promote growth of silicon nanowires, for example, on such surfaces it has been found by the inventors of the present invention that a barrier layer may be needed.

#Text=For silicon nanowires, the barrier layer can be, for example, a thin (e.g., approximately 1 to 20 nm, e.g., about 1 to 10 nm, e.g., about 5 to 10 nm) layer of microcrystalline silicon that is conformally deposited via Chemical Vapor Deposition (CVD) or other suitable technique such as sputtering or Atomic Layer Deposition (ALD) on the substrate surface prior to growth of the wires.

#Text=This thin silicon layer helps promote silicon nanowire growth and prevents any contamination or detrimental contaminants (e.g., nickel) from rising to the surface during the elevated temperature process.

#Text=Accordingly, silicon nanowire growth on stainless steel, titanium, nitinol, and possibly many other materials can be improved with the provision of a thin silicon layer that is conformally deposited onto the materials' surface.
#Text=The invention contemplates many different shaped surfaces, including planar surfaces and even complex three dimensional shapes and shapes having voids therein, even microcellular voids.
#Text=The invention contemplates voids as small a 1 micron in diameter, with preferred ranges between 10 and 100 microns.
